comment.body: Added a commit that removes them.

pull_request.title: kyber/dilithium aarch64 pull from pqclean + patches
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

- Runs copy_from_upstream with pqclean code, updating kyber and dilithium for aarch64
- Updates upstream patches & adds a few more fixes 
- Fixes a compiler warning in the arm aes code (https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/1506#issuecomment-1641645941)
- Fixes #1506 #1320
- Updates a few pqclean upstream licenses. 
- adds a falcon update from pqclean upstream
- updated dilithium suppression files (changed line numbers) -> CT tests passing using Fedora/aarch64

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

TODOs: 

- [x] KATs of 2 out of 3 Kyber versions (768, 1024) seem to fail with the updated upstream code.
@Martyrshot did you face any similar issues when including the previous code?
- [x] Update license infos

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -22,9 +22,9 @@ primary-upstream:
   spdx-license-identifier: CC0-1.0 or Apache-2.0
 optimized-upstreams:
   pqclean-aarch64:
-    source: https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/commit/d742438e5c541958bfd58070cd8668d757d88e07
+    source: https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/commit/66e50172055aaf1b9a16d8f35fe03b0807f2723e
       with copy_from_upstream patches
-    spdx-license-identifier: CC0-1.0
+    spdx-license-identifier: (CC0-1.0 or Apache-2.0) and (CC0-1.0 or MIT) and MIT
comment.body: A question regarding this SPDX documentation: Am I assuming right that this has been manually created from the single source code LICENSE files? In addition, is it intentional (and legal) to not include the actual LICENSE file(s) from PQClean? When looking at the contents of those (example: https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/blob/master/crypto_kem/kyber1024/aarch64/LICENSE) the documented upstream license does not seem to be in line with the SPDX statement in this PR -- or am I overlooking where Apache-2.0 is granted for the whole of the `aarch64` kyber code base? Or did https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/pull/488 simply fail to update the main LICENSE file?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -26,7 +26,7 @@ nist-round: 3
 spec-version: NIST Round 3 submission, v3.1 (June 10, 2022)
 spdx-license-identifier: CC0-1.0
 primary-upstream:
-  source: https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/commit/d742438e5c541958bfd58070cd8668d757d88e07
+  source: https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/commit/66e50172055aaf1b9a16d8f35fe03b0807f2723e
comment.body: Similar (license documentation) question here: This states CC0 -- which is textually correct looking at the immediate [LICENSE upstream in PQClean](https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/blob/master/crypto_sign/sphincs-sha2-256s-robust/clean/LICENSE). When looking at the ultimate origin code base [Sphincs+ is multi licensed](https://github.com/sphincs/sphincsplus/blob/master/LICENSE). If we manually "curate" license statements (see comment on kyber above) why not do the same with Sphincs+? This would resolve #1437 without having to push LICENSE statements "through" PQClean.
